context: Shooting as practised in Britain, as opposed to traditional hunting, requires little questing for <a0_0>game<a0_0/>—around <a1_0><a5_0><b10_0>thirty-five million<b10_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/> birds are released onto shooting estates every year, some having been factory farmed. Shoots can be <a2_0>elaborate<a2_0/> affairs with guns placed in assigned positions and assistants to <a9_0>help load shotguns<a9_0/>. When in position, <a3_0>"<a6_0><b14_0>beaters<b14_0/><a6_0/>"<a3_0/> move through the areas of cover, swinging sticks or flags to drive the game out. Such events are often called "drives". The <a4_0>open season for grouse<a4_0/> in the UK begins on <a7_0><b11_0>12 August<b11_0/><a7_0/>, the so-called <b12_0>Glorious Twelfth<b12_0/>. The definition of game in the United Kingdom is governed by the <a8_0>Game Act <b13_0>1831<b13_0/><a8_0/>.
